1 \defgroup understanding-send-latency Understanding Send Latency
2 \ingroup advanced-programming
3 
4 \details
5 
6 The overall latency of the OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::send method includes all latencies of all operations inside this
7 method.
8 The following sequence of operations are performed when the OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::send method is called:
9 
10 - Writing necessary data (message content, timestamp, sequence numbers, etc.) to the session storage.
11  For the \ref file-based-session-storage, it is a costly operation, and it can take tens of microseconds.
12 For the \ref asynchronous-file-based-session-storage, it is far cheaper, because the actual writing is performed in a
13 separate thread.
14 And lastly, for the \ref memory-based-session-storage, it is a low-cost operation, because data is stored in the
15 memory, not in the file system.
16 Please note, that if the OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::logBeforeSending option is false, then \ref logging-after-sending
17 "the logging is performed after sending".
18 - Invocation of the OnixS::B3::BOE::SessionListener::onMessageSending callback.
19 - Invocation of the system `send` function.
20 In practice, the latency of the system `send` function can be about 5-10 microseconds what depends on the size of send
21 data, network workload, network software/hardware, etc.
22 For example, you can significantly decrease this latency by using [Solarflare](https://www.solarflare.com) network
23 cards and the [user-space "Onload" TCP stack implementation](https://www.openonload.org/).
24 - If the system `send` function fails, then the unsent message is stored in the sending queue for the subsequent sending
25 by \ref threading-models "the sending thread".
26 
27 The latency of OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::send method (as any other function) depends on the frequency with which you call
28 it.
29 When you call a function infrequently, the function path and associated data structures will not be in a processor
30 cache, and this can increase the function latency.
31 However, if you call a function frequently, then you can avoid cache misses and keep the function path fast.
32 For this purpose, there is the OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::warmUp method, please see \ref session-warmup.
